"Tiny particles. Everywhere, invisible. "

The word dust comes from Old English dūst, meaning "dry, powdery matter"—fitting, since it’s just broken bits of dead skin, dirt, pollen, and even space debris.

Dust seems harmless, but it’s a silent architect. A single speck can float for days, riding air currents like a leaf on a river. Under a microscope, it’s a jagged mix: 70% dead skin cells, 30% fabric fibers, pollen, or soot. Some dust even drifts from the Sahara, crossing oceans in weeks.

It builds mountains—slowly. The Great Pyramid’s stones wear down into dust over millennia. In homes, dust bunnies form where airflow stops, trapping more particles. NASA studies cosmic dust to trace star births; a grain might be older than Earth.

Three related subjects are:
Pollen’s hidden journeys—how plants use wind like dust does.
Space dust’s role in planet formation—tiny seeds of worlds.
How dust storms reshape deserts—nature’s sandblaster.
